meta.mt2: Paul's first letter to the believers in

meta.ip: This is Paul's first letter to the believers in Corinth that we have in our Bibles, but could easily have been his second letter to them. We deduce this from his reference to other letters, e.g., see https://www.GotQuestions.org/how-many-letters-Corinthians.html, but we don't have copies of them.

In this letter from Paul to the believers in Corinth, he wrote about his time preaching in Ephesus. He wrote this in order to help with problems experienced by various groups of believers that he founded there in Corinth. Corinth was the mother city of province of Achaia—Achaia was a province of Rome. At that time, Corinth was a large city that Greeks, Romans, and Jews all lived in. And/Now from because ilis sika of dahat, many also the egmangendiye board of ships the egpamelegye and egpameli. Nabantug the sika city tenged of karatu din, and many the various religion of mahinged dutu, and many also the egmeyibhilabetey dutu and the following of tapey batasan like that. Hapit migdaruwa year(s) Paul the Lived there in order to preaching, and many the believed (Acts 18).

After around three years had passed while Paul was there in Ephesus preaching, nakarawat sikandin of letter from believers there to Corinth (1 Cor. 7:1). Nakarineg again sikandin concerning the ehetanan of believers and of other pad problems ran there to group of believers. Te this letter, advised din them concerning due and egpepaaween din that egmeyibhilabetey sakup of group dan of believers. He answered again that questions concerning the marriage, widows, gifts of Spirit of God, and the peg-uyag of me minatey.
In chapter 13, it tells how that love is an amazing gift from God to his people, in fact that's the overall theme of this document.

It's helpful to understand that this letter (and most Biblical documents) were dictated to scribes (who didn't have word processors) so in terms of sentence structure, the discourses are often not edited or placed in their time sequences more correctly as we would do with modern documents, but rather we notice a lot of long, rambling, run-on sentences (like this one) which we sometimes break into shorter sentences to help our readers, but try not to do it too often as it tends to remove the connections between the thoughts and can even lead to the bad habit of people quoting verses out of the context in which they were written.

io1: The scolding by Paul of believers tenged of ignoring dan of migpeyilabetey
The correct peggamit of kaligwangan isip believers
The respecting of God du of false gods
The correct eggimuwen of woman there to gathering of believers
The correct eg-ikulen of making of Peglabung of Master
The wisdom/knowledge given by Spirit and the peggamit due there to gathering of believers
The peg-uyag of the messiah and of believers
The collection of aid for Christians in Yudea
Paul's future plans and the conclusion
